questions.text: Which amino acid donates nitrogen to sodium benzoate when given for urea cycle disorders?
Nitric oxide is derived from:
questions.explanation:
Product

Description

Nitric Oxide (NO)

A signaling molecule involved in various physiological processes

Creatine

Plays a role in energy metabolism and muscle function

Polyamines (Putrescine, Spermidine, Spermine)

Essential for cell growth, proliferation, and differentiation

Ornithine

Precursor for the synthesis of polyamines

Urea

Produced as a byproduct of the urea cycle

Proline

Non-essential amino acid with structural and regulatory functions

Glutamate

A neurotransmitter and important metabolic intermediate

Agmatine

Involved in neurotransmission and regulation of nitric oxide

questions.text: What is the function of proteasomes?
Replacing alanine by which amino acid, will increase the UV absorbance of protein at 280nm wavelength?
Which of the following methods cannot be used to precipitate proteins?

options.label: C
options.text: Moving pH away from isoelectric pH

questions.correct_answer: C. Moving pH away from isoelectric pH
questions.explanation:
Method

Mechanism of precipitation

1. Heat

2. Strong mineral acids
  • Cause precipitation by denaturation

3. Heavy metal salts in alkaline medium

In alkaline medium

  • Proteins are negatively are positively charged
  • So, Neutralization of charges occur which leads to precipitation known as positive ion precipitation

4. Alkaloidal reagents (Trichloroacetic acid, phosphotungstic acid, sulfosalicylic acid)
  • Alkaloidal reagents are negatively charged
  • In acidic medium , protein are positively charged
  • So, Neutrialization of charges occur & leads to negative ion precipitation

5. Organic solvents e.g. alcohol & acetone

6. Neutral salts e.g. ammonium sulfate
  • Both cause precipitation by dehydration of proteins

A farmer sprayed a chemical in the pool which causes inhibition of complex-III of the electron transport chain. Identify the inhibitor?
questions.explanation:
Inhibitor

Target Site

Mechanism

Rotenone (Option A)

Amobarbital

Piericidin A

Complex I

(NADH dehydrogenase)

Blocks electron transfer from Complex I to ubiquinone​

 

TTFA (Thenoyltrifluoroacetone) (Option B)

Carboxin

Complex II

(Succinate dehydrogenase)

Blocks electron transfer from Complex II to ubiquinone​

Malonate

Complex II

Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of Complex II.

Antimycin A (Option D)

BAL

Complex III

Cytochrome bc1 complex

 

Blocks electron transfer from Complex III to Cytochrome C.

Cyanide (CN−) (Option C)

Carbon monoxide (CO)

Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S)

Complex IV

(Cytochrome c Oxidase)

 

Prevents electron transfer from Complex IV to oxygen​

Oligomycin

ATP Synthase (Complex V)

 

 

Blocks the proton channel of ATP synthase, preventing ATP synthesis​

Atractyloside

Adenine Nucleotide Translocase

Blocks ADP/ATP exchange across the mitochondrial membrane​

questions.text: If the RNA sequence is CAAGGU, what is the sequence of the template strand of DNA?
A patient presents with arthritis, and arthroscopy reveals blackening of the joints. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Alkaptonuria (Homogentisate Oxidase Deficiency)

Deficient Enzyme

Homogentisate oxidase

Accumulated Metabolite

Homogentisic acid

Key Features

Black urine (on standing), ochronosis (dark connective tissue pigmentation), early-onset arthritis

Affected Areas

Joints, cartilage (ear, sclera, intervertebral discs)

Diagnosis

Urine darkening with alkalization, elevated homogentisic acid in urine

Treatment

Low-protein diet (restricting phenylalanine & tyrosine), vitamin C, symptomatic management

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids primarily acts as a buffer in blood due to its ability to accept and donate protons at physiological pH?
questions.explanation:
Amino Acid

Buffering Ability

Reason

Histidine

Strong buffer

Imidazole group has pKa ~6.0, close to physiological pH

Arginine

Poor buffer

Guanidinium group has pKa ~12.5, too high to act as a buffer at pH 7.4

Tryptophan

Minimal buffering

Indole group is non-ionizable at physiological pH

Tyrosine

Minimal buffering

Phenol group has pKa ~10.1, too high to be effective

questions.text: Ammonia is transported from the brain to the liver in the form of which amino acid?
questions.explanation:
Transporter

Formation Process

Source

Destination

Mechanism/Role

Glutamine

Formed from glutamate and ammonia by glutamine synthetase.

Skeletal muscle, liver, CNS

Liver, kidneys
  • Transports ammonia from the brain and intestine to the liver. In the liver, glutamine is cleaved by glutaminase to release ammonia and glutamate.
  • Glutamate is then deaminated by glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH), releasing additional ammonia, which enters the urea cycle for detoxification.

Alanine

(Option B ruled out)

Formed from pyruvate and ammonia in muscles during the glucose-alanine cycle.

Muscles

Liver
  • Transports ammonia from muscle to the liver. In the liver, alanine is transaminated by alanine transaminase (ALT) to form pyruvate and glutamate.
  • The pyruvate is used to synthesize glucose, and the glutamate can be deaminated by GDH to release ammonia for the urea cycle.

questions.text: Aromatic ring is seen in which of the following amino acids?
questions.explanation:
Amino acids

Examples

Basic amino acids

Arginine, Lysine, Histidine (Option D ruled out)

Acidic amino acids

Aspartic acid, Glutamic acid

OH group-containing amino acids

Serine, Threonine, Tyrosine

SH group-containing amino acids

Cysteine, Methionine (Option C, D ruled out)

NH2 group-containing amino acids

Asparagine, Glutamine

Aromatic amino acids

(Option B)

Phenylalanine, Tyrosine, Tryptophan, Histidine

Aliphatic amino acid

Glycine, Alanine,

Branched chain AA (Valine, Leucine, Isoleucine) (Option A, D ruled out)

Imino acid

Proline

Purely Ketogenic

Purely Glucogenic

Both Ketogenic and Glucogenic

On catabolism gives only acetyl CoA

On catabolism gives only pyruvate

Substance on catabolism gives one of the glycolytic intermediate - Pyruvate or TCA cycle intermediate other than Acetyl CoA

Amino acids are:

  • Leucine
  • Lysine

Amino acids are:

  • Alanine: On transamination yields pyruvate.
  • Glycine: Simplest amino acid.
  • 3-hydroxyl group- containing amino acids
    • Serine
    • Threonine
    • Hydroxyproline
  • Sulphur-containing amino acid
    • Cysteine

Amino acids are:

  • Aromatic amino acids
    • Phenylalanine
    • Tyrosine
    • Tryptophan
  • Branched-chain amino acid
    • Isoleucine

Essential amino acids

Non-essential amino acids
  • The human body cannot synthesise them, which must be obtained through the diet.
  • They are crucial for various physiological functions, including protein synthesis, tissue repair, and enzyme production.
  • The human body can synthesise these, which do not need to be obtained directly through diet.

Examples:

  • Methionine
  • Arginine
  • Threonine
  • Tryptophan
  • Valine
  • Isoleucine

  • Histidine
  • Lysine

questions.text: A patient who was in excruciating pain all over his body was taken to the hospital. In recent years, he has experienced these incidents frequently. When exercising vigorously, the ache begins. Anemia was detected on blood examination along with elongated RBC as opposed to concave ones. It was determined that he had sickle cell anemia. What substitution takes place in sickle cell anemia?

options.label: A
options.text: Substitution of valine by glutamic acid at the 6th position

options.label: B
options.text: Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at the 6th position

options.label: C
options.text: Substitution of valine by glutamic acid at the 5th position

options.label: D
options.text: Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at the 5th position

questions.correct_answer: B. Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at the 6th position
